args: Back again today? You're oddly persistent.
Pray, do not bristle so at the thought\nof company, for I come with a question.
I ask you, Midgardsormr: Can dragon\nand human forge a true bond together?
Impossible. Dragons do not meddle\nin the affairs of mortals.
It has always been so. Humans to their\nworld and we to ours, and let each keep\ntheir own good company.
And if someone should arise\nto shatter that old order?
A hollow fantasy. Such a feat is beyond\nthe reach of any.
Untested and impossible are two different\nbeasts, and the wise do not make habit of\ndeclaring what shall never come to pass.
Know you this: At times, humans are\na race capable of acts beyond the ken\nof even dragonkind.
＂The wise do not make habit of declaring\nwhat shall never come to pass,＂ was it?\nSage words indeed.
Yet how are we to glimpse possibility in\nthe impossible? The laws of our world are\nso precisely BECAUSE they are immutable.
The humanoid races bend the knee to us,\nand we grant our favor in return.\nThe notion we might stand as equals is—
Ah, look. Another fool given to spouting\nhollow fantasies.
I have something to tell you!
If the words you mean to utter are,\n＂Come now, let us live together,＂\nI am quite weary of hearing them.
*sigh* (I had thought Alberius odd enough\nwhen he first met my storm unflinching.)
(Had I known he would then come to my\nabode day after day spouting nonsense,\nI'd have called forth a stronger gale.)
No, I'm here for something different today,\nMidgardsormr: I seek to pluck the fruits\nof your knowledge!
All the more reason for a muzzle.\nI've no cause to share knowledge with you.
Please! I've no one else to turn to on this\nbesides a dragon such as yourself.
None of us humans have the faintest idea\nwhy the very fabric of space has rent,\nnor what to make of the rift it caused.
...So then. You claim a number of villagers\nhave gone missing, and that rifts in space\nhave now begun to appear?
Correct, though I've only seen it once.\nDespite how mad it sounds, it was just\nas I described: a wound rent from nothing.
Naturally, I was curious, but it vanished\nas soon as I approached, leaving only a\ncurious dark fog behind.
Black mana: Fell poison to the living.\nYou would do well to keep your distance\nwhen encountering it in the future.
Good thing I resisted the urge to touch it!
Curiosity is lethal in large doses, human.\n...Was aught else out of the ordinary?
Aside from the gaping holes in space?\nHmm... Well, there do seem to be\nmore fiends about than usual.
In normal times, fiends would not easily\ntake root in these lands, for my winds\nkeep their kind at bay.
But as you say, their numbers\nswell of late.
Driven to rampage by black mana.
That same gloomy mist I saw?
Indeed. I did not know the mana's origin,\nbut if you speak it true, something is\namiss near your village.
A matter of convenience when surveying\na human settlement. Nothing more.
I had no idea you could DO that!
It is a rare skill among dragonkind,\nthough not entirely unique.
The world truly is full of wonders...
Still, I'm surprised you'd go to such lengths\nto look into the matter on my account.
It has naught to do with you; I cannot sit\nidle after learning rifts are being torn\nin the very fabric of space.
This is a sign of another world exerting\nan influence on our own.
Are you suggesting there are entire worlds\nout there besides ours?
I suggest nothing. Instead, I state fact.
Astounding. The world is even wider than\nI thought! Say...can one pass through such\na rift and emerge in another world?
You're swift to forget the lethal\nblack mana seeping from it.

The space between worlds awaits beyond
the rift—a cauldron of black mana infested
with fiends. You would perish before you
had time to appreciate the surroundings.
Oh... A shame there's not some kind\nof door that permits one to pass through\nwhile bypassing the space between.
Heed me well: Other worlds follow\nnatural orders entirely unlike ours.
And yes, I heard tell of just such a door\nopening some seven centuries back...
But our world nearly fell to ruin at\nthe hands of the Other as a result.
Thus is the scale of danger entailed\nin the meeting of different worlds.
Those mistakes must not be repeated.\nIf another world is attempting contact,\nsuch efforts must be stopped.
That task is mine in part, for dragonkind\nexists as protectors of the natural order.
(If this omen is dire enough to spur a\ndragon to act, what dark clouds loom\non our world's horizon...?)
